Subject: Re: [neat] HybrID: A Hybridization of Indirect and Direct Encodings for Evolutionary Computation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=236201729; y=E5XflSrGuuyPrBr-SehgJQxjPjwsbx6t26GXb584lkdSAag1

                      Hi Jeff,

Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote :

| Hello all-

| Recently I have shown that HyperNEAT has trouble making exceptions to the
| rules it discovers (Clune et al. PPSN 2008). I would like to introduce a new
| paper that will be at ECAL 2009 which shows one way to remedy this problem:
| combining a generative encoding (HyperNEAT in this case) with a direct
| encoding (FT-NEAT in this case).

Thanks for sharing this interesting paper.

If I understood your paper well, you first evolve the topology of the
NN with HyperNeat then fix the topoloy and only evolve the weights. Am
I right ?

May it be an instance of a global search (HyperNEAT) followed by a
local search (optimizing the weights) ?

Another point of view may be that HyperNeat is good at evolving the
topology (we only have to know if the output of the CPNN is above the
threshold) but not the precise weights.

Best regards,
-- 
Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
